(IMO Short list 2008, C2) Let Xn be the number of permutations of {1, 2, . . . , n} that have the given property, and let Yn be the number of permutations of {2, 3, . . . , n + 1} that have the given property. Note that 2(a1 + a2 + . . . + ak) ≡ 2 ((a1 − 1) + (a2 − 1) + . . . + (ak − 1) )(mod k), so we can always subtract one from each a1, a2, . . . , an without changing the problem. In particular, this means that Xn = Yn. It is easy to check that X1 = 1, X2 = 2, and X3 = 6. From now on, we will assume n ≥ 4. We have 2(a1 + a2 + . . . + an) = 2(1 + 2 + l · · · + n) = n(n + 1) ≡ 0(mod n), so a permutation need only satisfy the given condition for k = 1, 2, . . . , n − 1. Examining the condition for n − 1, we see that (n − 1)|2(a1 + a2 + · · · + an − an), so (n − 1)|n(n + 1) − 2an. This says that 2an = 2(mod n − 1), so either an = 1, n or n is odd and an = n+1 2 . Suppose we’re in the latter case. Then examining the condition for n − 2, we get (n − 2)|2(a1 + a2 + · · · + an − an − an−1), so (n − 2)|n2 − 1 − 2an−1. But this implies 2an−1 = 3(mod n − 2), and since n − 2 is odd, this has the unique solution an−1 = n+1 2 , which contradicts an−1 ̸= an. So we must have an = 1 or an = n. This means that Xn = Xn−1 + Yn−1 = 2Xn−1. For n ≥ 3, we therefore have Xn = 3 · 2n−2. 2. These values are all positive since d > a. Since x + y − z = a > 0, we can substitute x, y, z into the given equation to get f (a) + f (b) + f (c) = f (d), which completes the proof of the claim. Now let g(x) = f ( √x). We have proven that g(a) + g(b) + g(c) = g(a + b + c) for all a, b, c > 0. Taking a = b = c = x, we have g(3x) = 3g(x). Taking a = b = 3x and c = x, we then have g(7x) = 7g(x). Taking a = b = 2x and c = 3x, we then have g(2x) = 2g(x). Now, taking a = b = x and c = (n − 2)x, we have g(nx) = 2g(x) + g((n − 2)x), so it follows that g(nx) = ng(x) for all positive integers n. For any positive integers p, q, we therefore have g( p q ) = 1 q · g(p) = p q · g(1) (*). Also, if a < d, then g(d) − g(a) = g(b) + g(c) > 0, so g is increasing. Since the rationals are dense in the reals, it now follows from (∗) that g(x) = Cx for some constant C > 0, and hence f (x) = Cx2. Conversely, if f (x) = Cx2, then f (x + y − z) + f (2 √xz) + f (2 √yz) = (x + y − z)2 + (2√ xz)2 + (2√yz)2 = (x + y + z)2 = f (x + y + z). Remark: It isn’t necessary to calculate x, y, z explicitly to prove the claim. One may also proceed as follows: First ﬁx the products xz and yz, and let z vary. Then if z is very small, x + y − z will approach inﬁnity, and if z is very big, x + y − z will approach minus inﬁnity, so by continuity of x + y − z as a function of z, x + y − z will take every possible value. From this point forward, we will assume p ≥ 7. Claim 1: If x ∈ [1, p − 1], then xp−1 ̸≡ (p − x)p−1(mod p2). Proof: By the binomial theorem, (p − x)p−1 ≡ x p−1 − p(p − 1) · xp−2 ̸≡ xp−1(mod p2) since p ̸ |x, p − 1. Claim 2: If x ∈ [1, p − 1], then xp−1 ̸≡ (x + 2p)p−1(mod p2). Proof: Again, the binomial theorem gives (x + 2p)p−1 ≡ xp−1 + 2p(p − 1) · xp−2 ̸≡ xp−1(mod p 2) since p ̸ |x, p − 1. Let us call a number x “good” if xp−1 ≡ 1(mod p2). By pairing up x and p − x for all x ∈ [ 1, p−1 2 ] , Condition 1 implies that at most p−1 2 numbers in [1, p−1] are good. Furthermore, 2 we already know that 1 is good. Now, if two consecutive numbers in [1, p] are not good, then the problem is done. Otherwise, the good numbers in [1, p] must be exactly 1, 3, 5, . . . , p − 2. Now, (3p − 6)p−1 ≡ 3p−1 · (p − 2)p−1 ≡ 1(mod p2), so 3p − 6 is good. However, we already know p − 6 is good, so this contradicts Claim 2. The proof is now complete. 3
